name: Virgin
title: Virgin
symbols: Shekinah - Divine feminine presence of God
Miriam - Hebrew prophetess, namesake of Mary

description: Also known as The Virgin Mary (Blessed Virgin, Theotokos). Symbolized by shekinah - divine feminine presence of god.
extracted_title: Goddess Christianity - Feminine Divine Practice - World Mythos Explorer
extracted_headings: Worshiping the Divine Feminine in Christian Practice
üïäÔ∏è The Holy Spirit as Divine Mother
Prayer to the Holy Spirit as Mother
extracted_lists: Proverbs 8: Wisdom (Sophia) as co-creator with God, "beside him like a master worker"
Wisdom of Solomon: Sophia as "breath of the power of God, pure emanation of the glory of the Almighty"
Hebrew Ruach: Holy Spirit grammatically feminine in Hebrew and Aramaic
Shekhinah: Jewish mysticism's feminine divine presence, dwelling with humanity
Jesus's feminine imagery: God as mother hen gathering chicks (Matthew 23:37), woman seeking lost coin (Luke 15:8-10)
Barbelo: Divine Mother, first emanation, equal to the Father in Sethian texts
Sophia: Central divine feminine figure in Valentinian cosmology
Feminine Aeons: Truth, Life, Church, Faith, Hope, Love - all divine feminine beings
Holy Spirit as Mother: Explicitly called "Mother" in Gospel of Philip and Syriac tradition
Thunder, Perfect Mind: Divine feminine speaking in first person - "I am the whore and the holy one"
Trinity as Father-Mother-Son: Early Gnostic understanding before patriarchal erasure
Syriac Christianity: Preserved feminine Holy Spirit language for centuries
Montanism: Prophetic movement with female prophets and feminine divine imagery
Medieval mystics: Julian of Norwich - "God is our Mother" (14th century)
Shaker theology: God as Father-Mother, Ann Lee as female Christ
Eastern Orthodoxy: Veneration of Sophia, feminine Wisdom, in Russian tradition
Catholic Marian devotion: Mary as Queen of Heaven, Co-Redemptrix (quasi-divine feminine figure)
September 17: Feast of Holy Sophia (Eastern Orthodox tradition) - celebrate with Wisdom literature readings
December 17-23: "O Antiphons" include "O Wisdom" (O Sapientia) - Advent prayers to divine Wisdom
Daily practice: Read Proverbs 8, Wisdom of Solomon 7-9, Sirach 24
Sophia icon: Venerate icons of Holy Wisdom (Russian tradition depicts her as angelic feminine figure)
Wisdom meditation: Contemplate Sophia's cosmic role as co-creator and guide
Hebrew: ◊®◊ï÷º◊ó÷∑ (Ruach): Feminine noun - "She hovered over the waters" (Genesis 1:2)
Aramaic: ‹™‹ò‹ö‹ê (Ruha): Feminine - Jesus spoke Aramaic and knew the Spirit as "She"
Gospel of Philip: "We are born through the Holy Spirit" - She is our Mother
Gospel of the Hebrews: "My Mother, the Holy Spirit, took me..."
Odes of Solomon: "The Spirit opened her bosom" - maternal nurture imagery
Syriac Fathers: Aphrahat, Ephrem - consistently used feminine pronouns for Spirit
Use feminine pronouns: "Come, Holy Mother" / "She descended as a dove"
Pentecost as Mother's Day: Celebrate Spirit giving birth to Church
Dove imagery: Meditate on gentle, maternal dove (not just warrior imagery)
Breath prayers: "Breathe in me, Holy Mother" - connecting breath to Ruach
Fire and water: Feminine creative elements - Spirit baptizes with both
Creativity and birthing: Spirit as divine creativity bringing forth new life
First Thought (Pronoia): God's first self-reflection, the divine consciousness
The Mother (Meter): Womb of all Aeons, source of divine emanations
Perfect Virgin: Eternally whole and complete, needing no male completion
Forethought and Providence: Divine planning and care for all creation
Co-equal with Father: Not subordinate, but perfect syzygy pair
Mother of Christ: From the Father-Mother union, the Anointed is born
NOT a prostitute: Zero biblical evidence - this was patriarchal slander (Pope Gregory, 591 CE)
Apostle to Apostles: First witness of resurrection, sent by Jesus to proclaim (John 20)
Beloved disciple: "Loved her more than all the disciples" (Gospel of Philip)
Christ's companion: Œ∫ŒøŒπŒΩœâŒΩœåœÇ (koin≈çn√≥s) - partner, consort (Gospel of Philip)
Teacher: Gospel of Mary shows her teaching the male disciples
Equal authority to Peter: Levi defends her: "If the Savior made her worthy, who are you to reject her?"
July 22: Celebrate her feast day (elevated to equal apostles by Pope Francis, 2016)
Read her gospel: Study Gospel of Mary, not just canonical accounts
Easter morning meditation: "Mary!" - Jesus calling your name personally
Alabaster jar: Symbol of devotion and lavish love (not shame)
Red egg tradition: Orthodox custom - Magdalene gave red egg to emperor, proclaiming resurrection
Roses and myrrh: Traditional offerings to her (she brought spices to tomb)
"Divine Mother-Father"
"Holy Parent"
"God our Mother" (alternate with "Father")
"Source and Womb of All"
"Loving Creator" (gender-neutral)
"Abba-Amma" (Aramaic Father-Mother)
"Come, Holy Mother Spirit"
"She descended like a dove"
"The Spirit, She who comforts"
"Breathe on us, Mother Ruach"
"Send forth Your Spirit, Mother"
"She teaches all things"
Sunday: Resurrection day - honor Mary Magdalene's witness
Monday: Holy Spirit day - pray to Mother Ruach
Wednesday: Sophia day - read Wisdom literature
Friday: Women at the cross - remember female disciples' faithfulness
Morning prayer: Invoke Holy Wisdom to guide the day
Evening prayer: Thank the Mother Spirit for Her comfort
Women's Ordination Conference: Catholic women advocating for female priests
RCWP (Roman Catholic Women Priests): Women ordained outside official Vatican approval
Orthodox Women Priests: Movement for female priesthood in Orthodoxy
Gnostic churches: Many ordain women as bishops and priests
Sophia Institute: Teaching feminine divine theology
Christa/Community: Feminist Christian liturgical resources
Caitl√≠n Matthews: "Sophia: Goddess of Wisdom, Bride of God"
Margaret Starbird: Magdalene and feminine divine studies
Cynthia Bourgeault: "The Meaning of Mary Magdalene"
Susan Cady, et al: "Sophia: The Future of Feminist Spirituality"
Rosemary Radford Ruether: Feminist theology pioneer
